Articles.Content:
So, I was driving around up north and saw a weird ribbon in the sky:

So I zoomed out trying to look at it:

It almost looks like a botched Aurora or something. Anyone else seen this?
Sometimes the orbit lines from the map view remain visible in the flight view, and sometimes the orbit lines become weirdly jagged; you were probably just lucky enough to have both happen.
Hmm, that\'s probably the most logical explanation. As long as it isn\'t some weird shader problem.
Looks like a beta version of an Aurora
Yes, I believe it was a graphical bug. However, I quite enjoyed them, as they gave me something to pretty up the vast emptiness of space.
That is, until they turn out to be blue laser shooting monoliths bent to end civilization.

That is, until they turn out to be blue laser shooting monoliths bent to end civilization.

Or UFO\'s sucking kows into their ships

Oh man... you\'ve gone and done it now. Over that rise there... right where the lights are coming from...

That\'s where 20th Century Fox has it\'s fake moon landing stage.

Oops. I\'ve said too much.

I\'ll... I\'ll be g*DISCONNECT*
That is a rocket challenge. If you successfully follow it to one of its ends, it unlocks a hidden part set. I wont give it away, but the runway is used for something!

Oh man... you\'ve gone and done it now. Over that rise there... right where the lights are coming from...

I was hoping for a pot of gold...

That is a rocket challenge. If you successfully follow it to one of its ends, it unlocks a hidden part set. I wont give it away, but the runway is used for something!

Haha, you should post this in the subreddit and see if you can get people to look for it.
You have discovered the Space Kraken having one of its raves. You best not let it know you saw it if it doesn\'t already. We all know how the Kraken can be.

You have discovered the Space Kraken having one of its raves. You best not let it know you saw it if it doesn\'t already. We all know how the Kraken can be.

Lost many a good ships to that kraken.
